2. The rake system moves in a direction opposite to the fabric formation, and can also move slightly forward before moving backward to ensure proper placement of yarns on the conveyor needles.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The weft insertion apparatus uses different groups of subnozzles spaced at varying intervals to produce different weft carrying forces for different weft threads.
2. The apparatus also uses a remotely controlled pressure regulator valve to adjust air pressure for the subnozzles based on the selected weft thread.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The invention provides a process for spinning bast fibres, involving twice health-preserving bast fibres, opening, cleaning, carding, drawing into strips, and spinning into yarn.
2. The process for blended spinning bast fibres and other fibres includes health preserving bast fibres, blending with other fibres, opening, cleaning, carding, drawing into strips, health preserving, and spinning into multi-fibre yarn.
3. The health preserving process for bast fibre strips or multi-fibre strips is conducted under temperature ranging from 30°C to 80°C, relative humidity from 80% to 100%, and duration from 2 to 14 hours.
4. The end breakage rate of the yarn or multi-fibre yarn is significantly reduced, averaging 150-200 times per hour for each machine when the yarn is 12 s in fineness.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The invention relates to rolls for use in nip presses, particularly in the manufacture of paper, textile material, plastic foil, and other related materials.
2. The sensing roll is configured with a second roll in a nip arrangement, with both rolls rotating to press matter between them in a nip region.
3. The sensing roll has a plurality of cross-directional positions along its length, with each position having a pair of sensors spaced 180° apart to measure pressure at that position.
4. The average pressure measurement at each cross-directional position is used to calculate and display the nip pressure profile for the press.
5. The invention also allows for the calculation and display of a rotational variability profile, which provides additional real-time information about the dynamics of the pressure readings.
6. The present invention can compensate for rotational variability in the sensing mechanism by calculating an average pressure value at each cross-directional position.
7. The invention can be used in collaboration with correcting instrumentation which can eliminate or compensate for pressure variability at locations across the sensing roll of the press.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The invention is an apparatus for supporting an electrical cord and holding an article, such as a spray starch can or a beverage container, on an ironing board.
2. The apparatus includes a releasable clamp for securing it to the ironing board.
3. The clamp has a "C" shape with an end portion, an upper leg portion, and a lower leg portion.
4. The upper leg portion engages the ironing surface of the ironing board, and the lower leg portion has an adjustment screw to secure the apparatus to the board.
5. The apparatus includes a flexible cord support with a first rod, a second rod, and a resilient spring section joining them.
6. The first rod has a helical bent portion at the upper end to receive the electrical cord, and the second rod has a foot pivotably and slideably received by an opening in a brace mounted to the clamp.
7. The apparatus includes a detachable article holder with a lower hoop, support bars, an upper hoop, and vertical supports.
8. The article holder is mounted to the clamp using tangs on the upper hoop that are received by openings in a second brace mounted to the clamp.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The buttonhole controlling device 18 is attached to a presser bar 16 of a sewing machine.
2. The device 18 consists of a foot pad 26 and a travelling assembly 28, which includes a work engaging shoe 30 and a plate 32.
3. The travelling assembly 28 is held in an initial position relative to the foot pad 26 by oppositely acting springs 58 and 62.
4. The travelling assembly 28 includes an anchor element 50 with a "V" notch 72 to center one side of a round button 73, and a gaging element 76 with a "V" notch 86 to center the other side of the button.
5. The gaging element 76 carries a tab 88 to actuate a tripping lever 20 on the machine during movement of the assembly 28, limiting the length of a buttonhole formed with the buttonhole device to that suitable for the button inserted in the travelling assembly.
6. An adjustable stop 96, including a screw 98, is mounted on the travelling assembly 28 to engage the tripping lever 20 and terminate the formation of a buttonhole.
7. The position of the adjustable stop 96 can be varied to precisely define the closure point of a buttonhole, preventing the formation of an open buttonhole or one in which stitches overlap.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The fabric treatment apparatus comprises a conveyor with an endless sieve belt for transporting the textile web along a substantially horizontal path.
2. A liquid applicator is disposed at a first station along the path to apply the liquid to the web during motion thereof along the path.
3. A suction device is disposed at a second station along the path at a point downstream of the first station for removing the liquid from the web by a suction process during motion of the web along the path.
4. The suction device extends transversely to the web and to the belt and is disposed below and substantially juxtaposed to an upper section of the belt.
5. A dwell stretch is disposed between the applicator and the suction device for conducting the textile web in a spread-out condition and in a single layer through at least one dwell loop.
6. In one embodiment, the dwell stretch is formed by an air pass with freely rotatable rollers guiding the web in vertically extending loops above the upper section of the belt.
7. In another embodiment, the dwell stretch includes a freely rotatable drum disposed above the upper section of the belt, with the dwell loop extending around the drum, and at least two rollers disposed laterally adjacent to one another below the drum for guiding the web to and from the drum.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The dry cleaner machine has an air flow system that brings ambient air into the access opening whenever the door is opened, preventing users from encountering solvent vapor fumes.
2. The air flow system is exclusive of the air recirculating system and minimizes the exhausting of residual solvent vapors from the tubs.
3. A separate intake fan and duct are provided, with the duct interposed between the access opening of the machine housing and the open ends of the interior tubs.
4. A normally closed valve is included in the duct to isolate the separate intake system from the solvent vapors developed during the cleaning cycle.
5. In response to the access door being opened, the intake fan is energized and the valve is opened, drawing air into the access opening and directly into the interposed duct.
6. Only the vapor immediately adjacent the open end of the tubs commingles with the intake air and is lost to atmosphere, while the vapors within the tubs are retained.
7. The air flow system helps minimize the loss of solvent and reduces the formation of streaks and swales in the cleaned clothes.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The invention involves spinning thermoplastic polymer filaments into a quench chamber, then using the quench fluid to draw the filaments through a continuous two-dimensional slot across the entire machine width, forming a linear plane of filaments with constant distribution across the machine width.
2. The quench fluid, usually air, is maintained cooler than the filaments and is supplied under pressure, with a portion directed through the filament curtain and removed as exhaust through ports.
3. The drawing slot is formed by two identical air knives spanning the width of the machine, with the bottom surfaces of the knives being co-planar and substantially horizontal.
4. The filaments and quench fluid exit the impingement slot to atmosphere, creating a highly turbulent mixing zone that aids in transferring quench fluid energy to fiber velocity and slows down the stream, resulting in improved web formation uniformity and isotropicity.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The sewing machine 1 is provided with receivers 94, 95, and 96 to detect ultrasonic waves transmitted from an ultrasonic pen 92.
2. The ultrasonic pen 92 is not connected to the sewing machine 1 via a cable and does not output an electromagnetic wave signal.
3. The sewing machine 1 calculates the specified coordinates E based on the detection timings T2 of the receivers 94, 95, and 96.
4. The sewing machine 1 does not acquire the transmission timing T1 of the ultrasonic wave and does not use the transmission timing T1 when calculating the specified coordinates E.
5. The sewing machine 1 calculates the specified coordinates E using Formulas (5), (6), and (7).
6. The sewing machine 1 controls sewing based on the position of the transmission source of the ultrasonic wave identified by the specified coordinates E.
7. The user can specify an arbitrary position on the work cloth 100 by touching the work cloth 100 with the pen tip 911 of the ultrasonic pen 92.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The invention provides a preparation for application onto cellulosic fabric, comprising wool particles or powder as a carrier for functional additives.
2. The wool particles or powder are of macrofibril size or smaller, demonstrating exceptional functional additive-carrying and retention ability.
3. The preparation enhances the durability of functional enhancements of cellulosic fabric materials.
4. Ultrafine wool fibre, often scrapped due to being too short and weak for spinning, is used in the preparation, making it environmentally friendly and economical.
5. In another embodiment, the preparation comprises powdered bamboo fibre as a functional additive, preferably nano-sized with a particle size of 1 μm or below.
6. The preparation provides good moisture management properties to fabric materials treated with it.
7. The method of preparing the wool-based preparation involves pulverizing wool to obtain ultrafine wool powder, forming an ultrafine wool suspension, and adding functional additives.
8. The method of preparing the bamboo-based preparation involves pulverizing bamboo fibre to obtain coarse bamboo powder, forming a suspension, and pulverizing the coarse bamboo powder into ultrafine bamboo powder.
9. The preparation is applied onto the cellulosic fabric material by printing, padding, or foam application.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The invention is a frame quilting machine with two separate computers: one for controlling the sewing machine functions and another for controlling the quilting table movement in X, Y, or X-Y directions.
2. The sewing machine computer can be reprogrammed independently of the table movement computer, simplifying the process of changing stitch patterns or auxiliary functions.
3. The table movement computer can be programmed using a computer aided design (CAD) program, allowing for the creation and duplication of individualized patterns.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The invention relates to a method of making a two-sided nonwoven fabric with a durable three-dimensional image.
2. The fabric is formed from a first precursor web with a first fibrous matrix and a second precursor web with a second fibrous matrix, separated by a fluid-pervious support layer or scrim.
3. The precursor webs are hydroentangled on a moveable imaging surface with a three-dimensional image transfer device.
4. The support layer acts as a fiber distribution control layer, limiting intermingling of the first and second fibrous matrices while providing sufficient resistance to delamination.
5. Optionally, the fabric may include apertures and the fibrous matrices may have a fiber modulus difference of at least 10%.
6. Post-entanglement treatments, such as application of a polymeric binder composition or surfactant, can be applied to enhance fabric properties.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The device comprises a stop that can be moved into the feed path of the strip of material and retracted after being contacted by the strip. The movement of the stop controls a signal transmitter for a setting means for the stop.
2. The stop is mounted on a two-armed lever that is biased by a spring and can be moved into a position in which the signal transmitter is actuated independently of the strip.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The invention provides a method for connecting two tape-shaped knit pieces using a flat knitting machine with at least a pair of front and rear needle beds, where one or both are movable. The method involves knitting two tape-shaped knit pieces with a boundary between them on one of the needle beds, overlaying symmetrical loops of the final course of both knit pieces across the boundary, and binding off the overlaid loops gradually until the two pieces are connected.
2. The method ensures that the end parts of both knit fabrics are joined, and the final end portion of the junction is prevented from loosening the stitch, without the need for separate sewing processes or manual linking, improving productivity and reducing manufacturing costs.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The traction element comprises stranded cables with a core strand sheathed by a flexible thermoplastic plastics material layer.
2. The thickness of the thermoplastic plastics material layer is in the range of 0.1 to 1 mm.
3. The stranded cables are embedded in a flexible thermoplastic plastics material jacket.
4. The production line for embedding stranded cables in a flexible thermoplastic material comprises a reel for unwinding the stranded cables, a device for precise orientation, a heater, an extruder, a cooling trough, a roller store, a cutting device, and a storage roller.
5. The extruder has a thread guide for the stranded cables and at least one matrix, which can be adjusted with and in relation to one another individually, in a plane P angled with respect to the cable plane.
6. The method for embedding at least one stranded cable in a flexible thermoplastic material involves degreasing and/or pretreating the stranded cables to improve adhesion, preheating them to a temperature of about ±20° C. of the melting temperature of the flexible thermoplastic plastics material sheathing the core strands, and sheathing them in the extruder with the liquefied plastics material.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The lockstitch sewing machine has a rotary hook with a bobbin housing that has a triangular shoulder with front and rear side faces on the loop cast-off side.
2. A spring rod extends between a front cam and a rear cam, with the bobbin housing taking support on the spring rod to hinder co-rotation with the hook body.
3. A capsule release device gives the bobbin housing a rotational impulse counter to the direction of hook rotation, creating a gap between the rear side face and the spring rod.
4. The needle thread loop moves unhindered through the gaps created by the shoulder and the capsule release device during the pull-back movement.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The invention provides methods for producing silicon-based nanowires and films using liquid silane inks by electrospinning.
2. The liquid silane inks can include an accelerant for increased setting or curing times.
3. The methods can produce polysilane nanowires and materials.
4. The methods can be used for continuous production of nanofiber strands and coated nanofiber strands.
5. The silicon-based fibers can be used as a component in a variety of composite materials such as electrode composites.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The arrangement for controlling thread tension in a spool creel has multiple controllers, each coupled to a different spool holder and simultaneously settable by fluid pressure.
2. Each controller has a brake rotor, an adjustable braking element, and a tensioning lever with a roller biased by threads, occupying an angular position dependent on thread tension and weight.
3. A biasing arrangement activated by fluid pressure is connected to each tensioning lever, allowing for central control of thread tension across the entire creel.
4. The biasing arrangement operates in addition to the weight force on the tensioning lever, altering thread tension and enabling rapid braking when the warping machine is shut off.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The sewing machine detector of the present invention uses flat, sheet-shaped light shielding discs to detect sewing machine needle positions and speed, reducing the thickness and complexity of the detecting section compared to conventional reflective discs.
2. The detector employs optical fibers for both detection and power indication, eliminating the need for separate lead wires and reducing the risk of electromagnetic interference.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The process for continuous production of viscose rayon yarns with a high degree of whiteness involves completing the coagulation of the yarn, washing it with water having a non-alkaline pH, and drying it. The coagulation index should not exceed 1, and the washing should reduce the amounts of total sulfur, sulfur bound as sulfides, elemental sulfur, iron, zinc, and lead to specified levels.
2. The water used for washing should have a pH between 4.0 and 5.5 and be free from calcium and magnesium ions in amounts higher than 1.5 mg/l and 1.0 mg/l, respectively. This water can be obtained by treating industrial water with weakly acid ion exchange resins.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The invention relates to a system for deaerating pulp after an oxygen bleaching process to facilitate washing.
2. The deaeration tank is a small, cylindrical tank with an open top, flat bottom, and a diameter of 0.75 to 1.5 times the diameter of the oxygen reactor.
3. The tank has an inlet pipe for the oxygenated pulp, an outlet for the deaerated pulp, and a tangential filtrate swirler inlet for introducing filtrate from the washer to create a swirling motion in the tank.
4. The inlet pipe is located between the top of the tank and the surface of the slurry, and extends across the tank to allow the incoming pulp to strike the side wall of the tank.
5. The outlet is located in the bottom plate of the tank, directly below the outlet of the inlet pipe, and has a larger diameter than the inlet pipe to accommodate the recycled filtrate added to the slurry.
6. The filtrate swirler inlet is located between the bottom of the tank and the surface of the slurry, and is designed to accelerate the filtrate to a velocity of 4.57 to 12.19 meters per second (15 to 40 feet per second) as it enters the tank.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The invention relates to biomimetic tendon-reinforced (BTR) composite materials with improved properties, including high out-plane stiffness and strength-to-weight ratio.
2. The basic structure comprises stuffer members with first and second ends, tendon elements interconnecting the ends in alternating fashion, and first and second panels bonded or attached to the stuffer members' ends.
3. The stuffer members can be parallel, vary in length, or aligned along lines extending from a common center point. The panels can be flat, convex, concave, or have different radii of curvature.
4. The stuffer members and tendon elements can be embedded in a matrix material such as epoxy, foam, rubber, or other filling materials.
5. The tendon elements can be tied, glued, or otherwise bonded at the points where they cross, forming "joints."
6. Hollow stuffer members and tendon elements in the form of bent wires can be used to simplify manufacture.
7. The invention can be applied to various structures, including those with curved panels, and can be optimized for specific applications such as vehicular, aerospace, and marine body parts.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The invention is a load-limiting device for dissipating energy during dynamic events, such as earthquakes, in structures like buildings.
2. The device is designed to undergo plastic deformation, forming plastic hinges that absorb energy and limit loads transmitted to other parts of the structure.
3. The device can be easily removed and replaced after plastic deformation, allowing for quick repair and minimal downtime.
4. The device can be adapted to various structural applications and brace configurations, making it versatile for different building designs.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The invention relates to a bedroom cabinet for providing a flophouse facility in existing buildings.
2. The cabinet is designed to be optimum for use as a flophouse with no bath room or for taking a nap.
3. It has a floor area approximately equal to the size of a bed and a height allowing a user to sit up.
4. The cabinet is completely enclosed except for a doorway.
5. The cabinet is composed of an outer casing and an inner casing, providing mechanical strength.
6. A clearance between the outer and inner casings forms a box for accommodating electric devices or user's belongings.
7. The clearance also houses wirings for interior electric devices.
8. The outer surfaces of the cabinet are flat, allowing for close stacking or adjacent installation.
9. In a further embodiment, spacer members with venting grooves are interposed in the clearance for natural ventilation and sound-proofing.
10. The cabinet can be assembled and disassembled for easy transportation and installation.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The invention provides a portable guard rail support for erecting temporary safety barriers at construction sites.
2. The guard rail support consists of a flat base plate, an upright column, rail support brackets, a kick board retaining flange, an angular brace, and a safety tie-off ring.
3. The support can be anchored to a floor or ground surface using expansion anchors or screws through holes in the base plate.
4. The rail support brackets and retaining flange are designed to accommodate wooden guard rails and kick boards, respectively.
5. The safety tie-off ring can be used to attach safety cables or weatherproof tarpaulins.
6. The guard rail support can be used to construct a safety barrier by securing it to a floor surface and attaching wooden guard rails and kick boards to the brackets and retaining flange, respectively.
</summary>

1. The invention uses pulsed power electrohydraulic (EH) and electromagnetic (EM) methods to enhance oil recovery (EOR) from oil-bearing formations.
2. The EH method generates strong acoustic vibrations that travel outward into the formation from one or more wells, while the EM method generates high-frequency acoustic vibrations through electromagnetic induction in the formation.
3. The invention combines these two effects to mobilize oil and increase production, with the EM-induced vibrations acting for a short time after the EH or EM pulse is initiated.
4. The invention uses a multi-level discharge device that allows sequential firing of several sources in one well in a time sequence optimized to continuously stimulate a large reservoir volume while the EH acoustic pulse travels further from the pulse well.
5. The invention also uses multiple pulse sources in multiple wells that allow the EM-induced vibrations to continue for a longer time, extending the range of coupled stimulation.
6. The invention uses multiple EH and EM sources placed in multiple wellbores and discharged to act as an array that stimulates production of the oil in a given direction or specific volume of the reservoir.
7. The invention customizes the discharge characteristics of the pulse sources to produce specific frequencies that activate specific scales of inclusions in the reservoir, optimizing the energy absorption and effective stimulation.
8. The invention uses EM pulse sources that do not generate a direct acoustic shock pulse, replacing the conventional spark gap discharge device with a single-turn magnetic coil that produces a magnetic pulse with no acoustic pulse effect.
9. The invention separates the fluids produced from the wellbore into its components, including associated gas, condensate, liquid hydrocarbons, helium and other noble gases, carbon dioxide, sulphur dioxide, pyrite, paraffins, heavy metals such as chromium, manganese and vanadium.

<summary>
1. The splice 200 includes wave plates 208 with transverse protrusions 210 that receive and seat transverse wires 104, 206 of the soil reinforcing element 100 and grid-strip 202, respectively.
2. The splice 200 is secured by connective devices 216 that extend through perforations 212 in the wave plates 208, clamping down on the longitudinal wires 102, 204 and preventing the soil reinforcing element 100 and grid-strip 202 from escaping.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The present invention relates to a plow blade design that provides fluid passage and points of fluid ejection, produced with basic manufacturing processes.
2. The blade construction includes a multiple component assembly, allowing for rebuilding and replacing worn parts.
3. The plow blade design is adaptable for both static plowing and vibratory plowing utilities.
4. Fluid is ejected at specific points along the plow blade to lubricate the sides of the blade/chute, reducing drag and friction.
5. The flow paths for fluid are defined by stacking leading edge sections with flow voids and welding or attaching them to a blade.
6. The plow can be tailored to provide fluid injection characteristics to match specific job requirements using traditional manufacturing processes.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The MCL StuccoRite® Cavity Wall Cavity System is a masonry cladding system that meets performance requirements of the Building Code, including structural integrity, durability, spread of fire, and external moisture resistance.
2. The system comprises proprietary plaster reinforced with pre-papered hot dipped galvanised zinc steel wire mesh and other reinforcement, applied in three coats to achieve a nominal thickness of 21 mm with a standard sponge or plastic float finish.
3. The plaster is applied over mesh stapled to 35 mm×40 mm nominal sized H3.1 or H3.2 treated vertical timber battens, providing a ventilated and drained cavity.
4. The system is completed by being waterproofed with the application of not less than a 2 coat paint system in accordance with Paragraph 9.3.7 of E2/AS1.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The safe has a valuables receiving chamber with a rectangular opening, inwardly extending ledges on opposing walls for placing a steel door, and grooves on opposite walls to retain the door. The door is inserted at an angle, pivoted, and then laterally displaced until it is fully seated and locked.
2. The door has a lock assembly on its reverse side with a latch bolt engaging a detent in one bar and reinforcing bolts on both sides of the lock bolt to prevent force transmission to the lock mechanism.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The invention relates to monitoring and measuring fluid pressures in geological formations, specifically to measure the pressure at a desired elevation without being influenced by pressures above or below.
2. The method involves cementing a conduit with a filter at its bottom end in a borehole at a desired location, and then pressurizing the conduit to clear it of cement grout during the cementing operation.
3. Once the cementing is complete, a fluid is introduced into the conduit to displace the cement grout around the filter, creating a fluid connection between the formation and the filter.
4. In some cases, a hydrofracture process can be employed to create a fracture in the geological formation laterally adjacent to the filter, allowing the formation pressure to be directly coupled to the input of the pressure measuring apparatus.
5. The invention also includes a pressure sensor arrangement comprising a connector block, a pressure transducer, a check valve, and a filter, all connected together and located in the borehole at the desired location.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The jointing structure comprises steps at the coaxially built traveling path ends with an expansion gap between, elastic members respectively mounted inside the steps, and a joint block mounted on the elastic members across the expansion gap.
2. The joint block blocks up the expansion gap to prevent tire fall-in and stuck-in situations while maintaining the expansion gap function.
3. The elastic members are mainly composed of laminated rubber, which is hard to be deformed vertically and easy to be deformed horizontally in a soft manner.
4. The joint block, supporting blocks, and intermediate joint blocks are made of the same concrete or high-strength fiber-reinforced concrete as the traveling path to minimize differences in level.
5. The method of mounting an elastic member involves joining the elastic members together across the expansion gap, fixing one side to the step, deforming the fixed elastic member toward the bridge girder axis, and then fixing the other side to the step.
6. The method allows for easy mounting of the elastic member without being affected by seasonal changes, temperature variations, or bridge girder ages.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The invention relates to an enclosed floor track system for use in a fluid treatment chamber to move wheeled trucks without contaminating the sanitary environment.
2. The track system prevents showered fluid or fluid flowing on the floor from entering the wheel channel area and becoming contaminated by the truck wheels.
3. In one embodiment, the track includes a wheel channel supported above the floor by legs, with one sidewall extending higher than the other and a cover plate overlying the channel.
4. The vertical space between the shorter sidewall and the cover plate accommodates the axle structure connecting the truck frame to the wheel.
5. The cover plate can be pivoted away from the wheel channel to facilitate cleaning.
6. In another embodiment, the track is structured to accommodate trucks with downwardly depending struts supporting the wheel structure.
7. The sidewalls of the wheel channel extend upwardly beyond the top of the wheel structure and include inflatable elastomer seals at the top edges.
8. When inflated, the elastomer strips form a seal around the wheel struts and against itself along the remaining length of the floor track.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The lock device comprises an engaging member (lock plate) and an engaged member (lock pin) that can be manually operated to lock and release the boom.
2. The engaging member is guided by a slot and a support pin, and is held in the lock position or the release position by touching a guide member with either a first or second surface of the engaging member.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The swimming pool vacuum cleaner of the present invention features a flexible platform with a central, vacuum portion that is adjustable relative to the pool bottom to regulate suction efficiency during cleaning.
2. The adjustment mechanisms are conveniently located on the top of the vacuum head and can be operated by hand without the need for hand tools.
3. The suction exerted by the vacuum head can be precisely regulated without adjusting the remotely located suction source.
4. The adjustment mechanisms can be provided in kit form for easy connection to certain types of existing pool cleaning devices without major retrofitting.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The apparatus of the present invention provides a sub-unit with a mandrel having a longitudinal bore, an upper collar section for engagement onto a section of pipe, and a threadably removable lower collar section for engaging a lower section of drill pipe. A retriever section is slidably movable between the end collars of the sub-unit and adapted with protruding members for engaging a wear bushing.
2. The retriever section is slidably engaged onto the mandrel section of the sub-unit via grooved sections running substantially the length of the mandrel, allowing vertical movement but preventing rotational movement of the retriever unit.
3. The retriever unit can be mounted onto a mandrel and connected onto drill pipe, allowing vertical play to prevent damage to the retriever unit or the wear bushing due to excessive weight below the retriever.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The tool has an outer body with a lower end attached to a stuck object or fish and an upper end.
2. Within the outer body, a mandrel extends uphole from the upper end and is connected to the surface through a string.
3. The mandrel has a passage in fluid communication with the passage in the string, allowing pressure to be delivered from the surface to lateral ports.
4. The tool features modular stacked piston units that increase the delivered power of the tool by orders of magnitude compared to prior art tools.
5. The mandrel has a lower end that marks the end of the passage and a nearby shoulder on which a drop-in plug can land to close off the passage.
6. The plug is preferably retrievable and has a fishing neck and a seal to help close off the passage and build pressure in it.
7. The lower end of the mandrel features openings that lead into a chamber, which is initially closed off by a dump valve to allow pressure buildup and movement of the mandrel.
8. The dump valve is cylindrically shaped with a seal ring that initially rides on a surface to hold pressure in the chamber as the movement of the mandrel stretches out the string connected to it.
9. At some point, the ring seal moves off the surface, breaking the seal and relieving the pressure built up in the passage, allowing the mandrel to continue moving downhole due to momentum.
10. With the pressure dissipated in the passage, the stretching of the string reverses, causing the mandrel and the piston(s) attached to it to move up relative to the housing, eventually closing off the passage again to allow pressure buildup and reversing the direction of movement of the mandrel to allow the next cycle to begin.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The retaining wall is made of precast concrete in two discrete, modular parts: a face panel with an integral counterfort and a base.
2. The face panel has at least two counterforts spaced apart evenly from ends of the face, extending perpendicularly from the face panel, and its base extends rearward.
3. Reinforcing bars (rebar) can be cast within the counterfort, with more longitudinal, approximately vertical steel reinforcements incorporated in the lower part of the counterfort.
4. The base is generally a rectangular or trapezoidal shaped platform, set on grade, and is generally solid with no substantial openings other than small openings for grout fill.
5. A shear key can be made between the face or counterforts and the base, with the voids between the shear key and bottom of the face panel filled with grout to solidify the connection.
6. The base has at least one opening sized to accept the downward-extending rebar ends from the counterfort, with the connection point between the counterfort and base made by inserting an end of a piece of rebar of one module into an opening in the other module and then sealing the connection with grout.
7. If circumstances require extra precautions to keep the base from sliding, measures can be taken such as texturing or roughening the bottom of the base, setting the base on shims and pumping flow-able grout through the base and into the void created by the shims underneath, or driving H-piles into the ground and setting the base on top of these piles for added stability.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The present invention provides a down hole heating system for oil and gas wells with high oil viscosity and/or paraffin blockage, aiming to improve flow rates.
2. The system focuses heat on the production formation to heat oil and paraffin in situ, allowing them to flow to the well bore for pumping.
3. The system includes a heating unit with electrical connections shielded from well bore pressures and hostile chemical agents to prevent electrical problems and ensure long-term operation.
4. The method of use involves installing the heating system with heat-retaining elements to focus heat on the producing formation and improve well flow.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The invention relates to a down hole tool for installing and removing objects in wells, such as stuck or lost tools.
2. The tool has an outer tubular body and an inner body structure that can move telescopically within the outer body.
3. The inner and outer body structures have a locking mandrel with a catch mechanism that has a locking position and an unlocking position.
4. The catch mechanism includes a pin structure that moves within pin receiving grooves to control the locking and unlocking of the tool.
5. A control spring ensures that the pin alternately enters one or the other of a pair of unlocking or locking grooves each time the inner and outer body structures are cycled linearly relative to one another.
6. The tool can be locked or unlocked by moving the inner and outer body structures linearly relative to one another.
7. The tool can be used for both external overshot and internal spear operations.
8. The tool can be adjusted to engage different surfaces on the object to be removed from the well bore.
9. The tool can be latched and unlatched multiple times without removal from the well bore for resetting operations.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The example embodiment relates to modular composed stave floors.
2. The known stave floors have a minimum material thickness of 1 mm for corrective maintenance, while the sight substrate has a thickness of 2-3 mm, leading to deformation and detachment upon sanding or rushing.
3. The base substrate of known stave floors is composed of slung wood or triplay, joined by glue, which can suffer deformations and changes of displacement between the substrates.
4. The cure or wait time for the glue to harden in known stave floors can stretch several days.
5. The life of known composed stave floors is short, with no possibility of providing corrective maintenance.
6. The example embodiment provides a method for the manufacture of composed stave floors with improved durability and corrective maintenance capabilities.
7. The method includes providing a sight substrate having a thickness of at least 4 mm and a base substrate having a thickness of at least 12 mm.
8. The base substrate and sight substrate are assembled together with glue and multidirectional holding means, including dendrites, adhesion and horizontal reinforcement means, and adhesion and vertical reinforcement means.
9. The example embodiment provides a composed stave floor with improved physical, aesthetic, and functional properties, and increased durability.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The invention provides a brace for a ladder that improves lateral stability by increasing the contact area with the work surface and preventing the ladder from slipping or sliding.
2. The brace assembly includes an extension arm with a resilient pad that pivots vertically or horizontally to allow the ladder to straddle corners without losing stability.
3. The brace assembly is attached to the ladder using a U-bolt that encircles a rung and a clamp that secures the arm to the siderail, preventing any motion of the arm towards or away from the siderail.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The present invention relates to a collated nail strip formed with a debris-free plastic material for use in a fastener driving tool.
2. The nail strip comprises a row of nails arranged substantially parallel to each other, with each nail having a shank.
3. A collation system is formed from a plastic material that is molded onto and adhered to the nails. The plastic material defines a collar portion that captures or substantially encircles the nail shank and a connecting portion extending between and connecting adjacent collar portions.
4. The plastic material is formulated from an adhesive polymer, such as a polyolefin, a polyolefin blend, an epoxy, or the like, and is preferably a blend of polypropylene and a maleic anhydride modified polypropylene.
5. The nails are preheated prior to molding the plastic material to the nails to enhance adhesion. A preferred preheating temperature is about 450° F. to 600° F.
6. The collation system is configured to minimize debris generation and corrugation of the strip, and to maximize the adhesion of the plastic to the nail shanks.
7. The collation system can be configured with weakened regions to influence separation of the connecting portion from the collar at a desired location, and can include notches, varying cross-sectional areas, or eccentric nail placements to achieve this.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The invention is a nozzle for applying sealants such as silicones, comprising a bell or hood lower section and an injection button.
2. The nozzle has a main elongated hollow body with a truncated cone shape, a first end with a wider diameter, and a second end.
3. The first end has a connecting hollow round section with a threaded exterior surface for coupling to a sealant cartridge or injection machine.
4. The connecting section has a protruding ring that acts as a stopper and reinforces the union between the nozzle and the cartridge.
5. The second end has a bell or hood shaped section that encapsulates rivets or nuts and provides a connection element for the injection button.
6. The injection button has a circular main body, a peripheral groove section, a hollow central circular protrusion, and multiple series of radially oriented channels ending in orifices distributed around the central circular protrusion.
7. The injection button may have lateral grooves or openings around the lateral sides of the central circular protrusion for directing the flow of sealing material towards the walls of the orifice in which the screws are inserted.
8. The nozzle is made of plastic, preferably polypropylene, and is coupled to the sealant containing cartridge or injection machine by threading the connecting hollow round section.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The invention describes a position sensor that modifies an unconditioned sensing signal from a transducer using an error correction signal to provide a conditioned sensing signal.
2. The error correction signal is generated by a circuit that constantly compares the conditioned sensing signal to a desired minimum value, adjusting it in two directions based on the speed of the object being monitored.
3. The sensor draws minimal current upon startup and initial calibration, and can be recalibrated at any time by removing and reapplying power.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The invention provides a desmodromic valve actuation system for internal combustion engines that eliminates the need for springs and allows for variable valve displacement.
2. The system uses a rotating cam and translating means to interact with a second controllable actuating means that controls valve position, enabling precise and timely control of valve opening and closing.
3. The invention is applicable to engines with multiple valves per cylinder and can be controlled by a central control system to optimize fuel consumption and engine performance.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The light member includes a housing with a top side and a bottom side, and a lighting control region on the bottom side with first and second control channels for different colors of light and a neutral channel. Light-emitting modules can be coupled to the lighting control region and are electrically connected to the respective control channels and the neutral channel.
2. The light member includes a switch assembly coupled to the housing that is operable to selectively deliver power to the first and second control channels, allowing for independent control of the different colors of light.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The invention relates to a cooled flow deflection apparatus for a fluid-flow machine operating at high temperatures.
2. The apparatus is a hollow casting with cooling channels separated by inserts acting as separating walls.
3. The inserts are separate from the apparatus and are inserted into holders in the form of rails.
4. The inserts are secured by an integral material joint, preferably by soldering or welding.
5. The inserts can be straight or bent into a U-shape for deflection of cooling fluid.
6. The apparatus is a blade in a gas turbine.
7. The cooling channels and inserts extend essentially in the radial direction with respect to the rotation axis of the gas turbine.
8. The inserts are secured at the end close to the axis for rotor blades rotating at high speed.
9. The inserts can be provided during blade production or inserted into completely cast blades as a replacement for cast separating walls.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The system automatically or manually controls a fuel delivery system, such as a throttle valve, based on signals from an accelerator pedal and throttle position sensor. It uses a control unit that processes these signals to generate control signals for a DC motor or stepper motor, which adjusts the throttle position for optimal vehicle performance.
2. The system allows switching between automatic and manual control. When switching to manual, the clutch connects the accelerator pedal directly to the throttle valve, providing full vehicle operation. The switch occurs only when the throttle valve position matches the accelerator pedal command or is in a predetermined position, preventing the vehicle from lurching or stalling.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The invention provides a waste fuel burner that emits minimal particulate materials, operates with little slag or clinkers, and can burn wet wood with up to 70% moisture content.
2. The burner is self-regulating, easy to control, and has fast response times to changes in load, comparable to conventional gas and oil burners.
3. The burner forms a conical pile of waste fuel, fed from below, with preheated underfire air percolating up through the pile to dry and gasify the fuel.
4. Volatile gases driven off the pile are partially oxidized by additional combustion air introduced tangentially with a vigorous swirl in a primary combustion chamber.
5. The amount of combustion air admitted to the primary chamber is maintained at less than stoichiometric proportions to keep the temperature lower than the melting point of the natural ash, dirt, or other inorganic substances in the fuel.
6. The swirl air forces particulate matter out of the gas stream leaving the primary chamber, and an air-cooled disc or flame holder further separates any remaining entrained particulate matter.
7. The volatile gases move around the flame holder into a secondary combustion chamber where secondary combustion air is introduced tangentially in an amount above stoichiometric proportions for complete combustion.
8. The secondary combustion air interacts with the swirl air to maintain good separation of the particulate from the gas stream leaving the primary chamber, keeping the particulate out of the secondary chamber where high temperatures could cause slag formation.
9. The burner can be coupled to any source of dirty particulate-laden combustible gas and effectively burn the gas to provide a source of useful heat and remove the particulate for meeting environmental emission standards.
10. The burner's control system adjusts the air and wood feed rate based on BTU demand, with overrides or trims provided on the swirl air and secondary air quantities to maintain optimal combustion conditions.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The invention provides an efficient evaporative air cooling system that separates the dry and wet sides of a heat exchanger to prevent water vapor from being added to the useful air.
2. The system uses a major portion, preferably all, of the working air from the load (enclosure to be cooled) to maximize the temperature differential and cooling efficiency.
3. The heat exchanger comprises an array of spaced, vertically directed hollow tubes through which fresh air flows on the dry side for cooling, while return air from the load flows countercurrently to water flowing downwardly along the inner surfaces of the tubes on the wet side.
4. The system includes a water reservoir, pump, and distribution manifold to ensure even water flow and evaporation along the inner surfaces of the tubes.
5. Optional features include recirculating a portion of the return air with fresh air to increase the cooling rate, and bypassing a portion of the cooled air to mix with the working return air for further cooling by the heat exchanger.
6. A hybrid system is also disclosed, which combines the evaporative cooler with a vapor compression refrigeration unit to dehumidify a minor portion of the useful air, further enhancing cooling efficiency.
7. The condenser coil of the refrigeration unit is placed in the discharge path of the wet side of the heat exchanger to reduce energy requirements.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The fluid pump comprises two or more pump heads configured in series, with each pump head containing an impeller driven by a drive structure.
2. Fluid flows sequentially through each pump head, entering through an inlet and exiting through at least two fluid conduits that combine into a single flow before exiting the pump head.
3. The initial pump head draws fluid from a reservoir, while the final pump head expels fluid through an outlet.
4. The drive structure passes through the inlet between the pump heads, commonly driving the impellers in each pump head.
5. The fluid pump cannot be constructed by simply stacking known pumps together due to the unique design features of the initial and final pump heads.
6. Intermediate pump heads have design features of both the initial and final pump heads to permit series flow of fluid and common driving of the impellers.
7. A pump assembly comprises a fluid pump mounted on a support structure, such as a wheeled boom, hitching assembly, or trailer.
8. The support structure permits operation of the pump at a fluid reservoir and may include features such as an agitator nozzle or immersion pipes.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The invention relates to engine compression release brakes, specifically for engines with less than all cylinders equipped with brakes.
2. Traditional engine compression release brake systems have a brake for each cylinder, but this can lead to excess components.
3. The present invention reduces engine components by using brakes on only a portion of the cylinders.
4. An engine is provided with an engine housing defining multiple cylinders, and an engine compression release brake for each of a portion of the cylinders, where the portion is less than all of the cylinders.
5. Each engine compression release brake is operably coupled to a cam actuated exhaust valve.
6. The engine compression release brake includes a hydraulic system with a low pressure reservoir, a high pressure pump, and a high pressure manifold.
7. The engine also includes an electronic control module in communication with one or more engine components, including the engine compression release brakes.
8. The engine compression release brake operates by opening the exhaust valve during the compression stroke of the piston, allowing compressed air to escape and providing engine braking.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The invention relates to a link assembly between an engine and a gearbox, comprising a male link, a female link that receives the male link to allow translation and forms a radial interface for dampening, and a pin to selectively retain the links.
2. The gearbox assembly includes the link assembly to couple the engine to the gearbox, with the male link coupled to one of the engine or gearbox, and the female link coupled to the other.
3. The radial interface between the male and female links dampens translation of the male link relative to the female link through coulomb damping.
4. The pin is designed to shear at a known load magnitude corresponding to the maximum structural capability of the gearbox assembly and the engine mounting structure.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The invention provides a lightweight point cap system with adjustable weight for perfect arrow balance, reducing material and weight of the point or broadhead.
2. The point cap system works with a balance pin whose weight can be adjusted to balance an arrow shaft.
3. The invention also provides means to attach points to arrow shafts without allowing dirt to enter the shaft when the arrow points are not attached, and to replace damaged point cap members without rendering the arrow shaft useless.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The Small Arms Firing Effect Simulator (SAFES) is an electronic device that simulates the sound and flash of small arms fire for training purposes.
2. It consists of an electrical control circuit, a bolt interface, a trigger interface, oscillators, a firing counter, a firing decoder, a firing control, firing sensors, and a Multiple Integrated Laser Engagement System (MILES) interface.
3. The bolt interface simulates the action of the weapon's bolt, enabling the device only when the bolt is open.
4. The trigger interface detects the trigger pull and initiates the firing sequence.
5. The oscillators generate timing signals for the firing sequence.
6. The firing counter and decoder determine the order in which the pyrotechnic charges are ignited.
7. The firing control ignites the pyrotechnic charges in sequence, allowing only two charges to be ignited at a time.
8. The firing sensors detect the ignition of a charge and signal the oscillator control to stop the firing sequence.
9. The MILES interface connects the device to a MILES unit for training purposes.
10. The device is packaged to resemble a magazine clip and is inserted into the weapon in the same manner.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The air intake device comprises a tank, a first pipe (5) with a valve (7), and a second pipe (6) with a smaller cross-sectional area than the first pipe.
2. The first and second pipes interconnect the tank with the intake passage at different locations.
3. The valve (7) is controlled by an actuator (8) responsive to engine operating conditions.
4. The cross-sectional area of the first passage is equal to or larger than that of the intake passage.
5. The cross-sectional area of the second passage is substantially equal to or smaller than about one-tenth that of the first passage.
6. The second passage opens to the air intake passage at a location nearer the air cleaner than the location where the first passage opens to the air intake passage.
7. The valve (7) is closed when the engine load is below a certain level (line n in FIG. 6).
8. The valve (7) is operated to open and close based on the engine speed and load, creating a compound curve of volumetric efficiency.
9. The second pipe (6) acts as a resonator to reduce intake noise.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The invention is a mounting bracket assembly consisting of a stationary bracket and an adjustable bracket.
2. The stationary bracket is mounted on a pole, pipe, column, wall, or other surface.
3. The adjustable bracket is attached to the object to be mounted, such as a speaker, lighting, signage, display, monitor, or video camera.
4. The adjustable bracket is positioned on the stationary bracket to mount the object on the surface or pole.
5. Tapered springs guide the two brackets together during initial mating.
6. The adjustable bracket is rotated into a locked position, and the two brackets snap together temporarily using integrated hooks and tabs.
7. Axel screws are inserted loosely through the adjustable bracket into locking threads in the stationary bracket to form a hinge.
8. The assembly is secured and ready for adjustment, with the ability to adjust the angle of the object from 0 to -70 degrees.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The burner has a combustion chamber enclosed by an outer wall surrounding a fuel holder.
2. Air flows through the fuel holder to support initial combustion and around the fuel holder to support secondary combustion.
3. A shroud provides a second wall surrounding the outer wall, establishing a flow path for tertiary combustion air.
4. The burner has legs holding the combustion chamber well above ground level and a pivotally coupled ash pan.
5. A perforate food grate is pivotally coupled to the burner and movable to a deployed position above the flame and to a stowed position to the side of the combustion chamber.
6. Opposite the perforate food grate, a cover is pivotally coupled to the burner to close the combustion chamber.
7. The burner has manual couplings for removably coupling modular heat utilizing appliances.
8. The modular heat utilizing appliances include closed and open cookers, a food smoker, a space heater, and a pyrolyzer.
9. The pyrolyzer includes a substantially air-tight heating chamber for pyrolyzing carboniferous materials and a condenser for condensing vaporized liquid products of pyrolysis.
10. The burner may be provided with a fuel feed feature to enable renewing the fuel supply during operation.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The invention aims to improve combustion efficiency and reduce housing structural failures by combining ignition and cooling systems effectively.
2. The housing structure facilitates circumferential cooling flow while minimizing thermal distortion, particularly around spark plug bosses.
3. The housing provides separate flow paths for boiling vapor release from multiple spark plug bosses interrupting the cooling circuit.
4. The staggered arrangement of spark plug bosses increases the heat transfer coefficient of the cooling circuit by at least 20% compared to prior art capabilities.
5. The housing structure employs flow diverters or controllers between spark plug bosses to ensure a controlled flow regime and strengthen the housing.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The invention is a method to minimize steam boiler pressure changes or turbine power changes during turbine control valve operational safety test stroking.
2. It uses control valve positions as feedback to minimize flow disturbance caused by the closing and reopening of a turbine control valve during periodic operational testing.
3. By maintaining the total mass flow through several parallel turbine inlet flow control valves constant, the steam generator pressure is maintained constant, and the inlet pressure regulator is unaffected during inlet control valve testing.
4. The flow is determined as a function of control valve position, and the flow change due to closure of one of the several parallel flow paths during valve testing is compensated for.
5. The method uses a test compensation circuit that adjusts the flow through parallel control valves to minimize flow disturbance caused by the closure and reopening of turbine control valve during testing.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The mixing valve system 5 allows continuous analog control of the proportional quantities of soap solution and water emerging from outlet passage 38, ranging from approximately 0% water, 100% soap solution, to 100% water, 0% soap solution.
2. The valve system 5 operates multiple identical systems from a common soap solution source and common water source without affecting fluid pressure required by each user, due to flow reduction mechanisms and the design of bores 54 and 56.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The method involves compressing gas in a compressor station for a gas pipeline, with an entry pressure, to a higher pressure, cooling the gas by heat exchange, and feeding it back into the pipeline with a lower exit temperature and increased exit pressure.
2. During warmer periods, the gas is compressed to an excess pressure substantially higher than the desired exit pressure.
3. The compressed gas is cooled by heat exchange to a temperature above the desired exit temperature.
4. The gas is then expanded from the excess pressure to the desired exit pressure, further cooling it to the required exit temperature.
5. The expansion can be carried out by throttling or using an expansion turbine, which can also perform work and recover mechanical energy.
6. The compression to the excess pressure can be carried out in three stages, with two primary compression stages and an additional compression stage.
7. The compressors in the primary compression stages have approximately the same pressure ratio, allowing for easy exchange between stages.
8. During colder periods, the compressor station can be operated in a parallel mode, using all compressors to achieve the required throughput quantity.
9. The method reduces investment costs and operation risks compared to conventional re-cooling technology using propane cooling cycles.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The invention describes a system for mounting a cooling fan to an enclosure without using fasteners like screws or dowel pins.
2. The fan assembly includes a motor carrier with mounting legs that have resilient leg portions and a spring member. The panel has recess portions with openings that correspond to the mounting legs.
3. The fan assembly is installed by first inserting the turned-out portions of the resilient legs into the enlarged opening regions of the panel's openings, then applying a combined compressive and rotating force to move the resilient legs into an intermediate opening, and finally rotating the assembly further to allow the resilient legs to spring out into the residual opening, securing the fan assembly to the panel.
4. The spring member urges the motor carrier away from the panel, preventing vibrational forces from causing the resilient legs to disengage from the residual opening and reducing vibrational noise.
</summary>

<summary>
1. Spacecraft structures require lightweight, stiff composite materials, but these materials lack inherent damping, leading to high vibration levels that can compromise instrument functionality.
2. Kinematic mounts (KM) are used to support instruments on spacecraft, but they have very little inherent damping, amplifying flight loads to the mounted instrument.
3. The present invention aims to provide kinematic mounts with novel damping features to protect instruments from potentially damaging flight loads.
4. The damping mechanism can be provided at machined hinge or flexure locations of the mounts, taking advantage of the most active portions of the mounts.
5. Two damper designs are proposed: a spherical damper and a cylindrical slot damper, both using viscoelastic (VEM) damping materials.
6. The spherical damper consists of two partial shells concentrically arranged with a layer of VEM damping material between them, while the cylindrical slot damper uses o-rings or washers made of VEM material placed within slots around the flexural hinges.
7. The damping materials dissipate vibration energy in the form of heat, reducing the high energy disturbances to the instrument.
8. The modified kinematic mounts preserve the fundamental features of strength, stiffness, and kinematic features while introducing a damping mechanism into the six mount suspension modes.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The clutch unit comprises separate piston and cylinder means for each set of clutch disc segments and clutch plates, allowing for maximum torque transmission and improved control accuracy.
2. The unit utilizes hydraulic fluid for both retracting the clutch plates to reduce residual drag and as a coolant for the clutch discs.
3. The clutch discs are segmented, allowing for easy removal and replacement of individual segments without disassembling the entire unit.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The invention involves downstream expansion cylinders associated with a combustion cylinder to lower the temperature of fluids, potentially eliminating the need for a radiator.
2. A catalytic material is placed on surfaces that "see" hot exhaust gases to achieve catalytic conversion of impurities within the engine.
3. Water is recovered from a system having both a water injection expansion cylinder and a combustion cylinder, and the recovered water is re-used for expansion.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The invention provides a plate consisting of a steel substrate and a precoat comprising an intermetallic alloy layer in contact with the substrate, topped by a metal alloy layer.
2. On at least one precoat face of the plate, an area situated at the periphery of the plate has the metal alloy layer removed.
3. The precoat is preferably an alloy of aluminum or based on aluminum.
4. The metal alloy layer of the precoat preferably comprises, by weight, from 8 to 11% of silicon, from 2 to 4% of iron, the remainder of the compound being aluminum and inevitable impurities.
5. The width of the area from which the metal alloy layer has been removed is preferably between 0.2 and 2.2 mm.
6. The width of the area from which the metal layer has been removed preferably varies.
7. The thickness of the intermetallic alloy layer is preferably between 3 and 10 micrometers.
8. The area from which the metal alloy has been removed is preferably produced by partly eliminating the metal alloy layer on at least one precoat face of the plate by brushing or using a laser beam.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The invention is a remote control system for supervisory control and data acquisition (SCADA) enabling navigation and automatic operation of a mobile structure that extracts energy from severe weather patterns.
2. The system optimizes efficiency by accounting for data from weather observations and sensors on the mobile structure, relating these data points to performance models for the mobile structure.
3. The mobile structure can be a sailing or propelled vessel or barge, or any mobile buoyant energy recovery system, such as the Turbine-Integrated Hydrofoil of U.S. Pat. No. 7,298,056.
4. The SCADA system gathers data through diverse means such as Global Position Satellite (GPS) systems, weather satellite systems, and telecommunications satellites.
5. The system includes computer servers running Human Machine Interface (HMI) secure software applications that communicate with microprocessor systems running client software with a Graphical User Interface (GUI) to allow remote humans to optionally interact and choose mission critical navigation plans.
6. The system can navigate vessels for logistics-only purposes past weather patterns using just the path cost algorithm without weighing energy extraction yield factors into the cost of travel.
7. The system can guide navigation of vessels for energy extraction using an algorithm that optimizes energy extraction using yield functions derived from weather and geospatial data and vessel performance models.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The rolling body guide cage is produced from a ring element composed of at least two flat material ring segments joined in succession in the circumferential direction and connected, preferably welded, before forming the axial profiling.
2. The flat material ring segments are joined across an engagement zone and welded along the edge regions facing each other therein, with positively engaging joint contours forming an undercut geometry.
3. The flat material ring segments are cut out, preferably punched out, from a sheet metal material and formed as 120° ring segments to minimize waste material.
4. The rolling body guide cage can be structured for radial or axial bearings, with the latter being composed of a first and a second ring element positioned in mirror-symmetry, preferably with offset weld points.
</summary>

<summary>
1. A service technician visits a customer service location with an input device to receive and transmit information related to service disruptions.
2. The input device is configured to access a technician server through a wireless data network or a modem connection.
3. The technician server processes information transmitted from the input device, including a user ID, password, radio serial number, and input device serial number.
4. The technician server functions as a transaction request broker between the protocol server and other systems, such as a global positioning satellite system, dispatch system, address guide system, and customer records system.
5. The global positioning satellite system is used to track, dispatch, and monitor service technicians and their input devices at customer service locations.
6. The dispatch system receives, processes, and transmits information related to service required at customer service locations.
7. The address guide system stores universal type address information and promotes valid addresses as customer service locations.
8. The customer record system stores customer-related information, including the customer's address and details of the service to be installed.
9. The technician server requests coordinates (latitude and longitude) from the service technician at the customer service location.
10. The technician server instructs the service technician to verify their presence at the customer service location, and the GPS system obtains the coordinates of the customer service location.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The system for compensating electromagnetic interfering fields comprises two real triaxial magnetic field sensors, three pairs of compensation coils, and a control unit to protect an object against influences of an interfering field.
2. The control unit combines the output signals of the two real sensors to three output signals of a virtual sensor using a freely definable kind of averaging.
3. The averaging is described by a matrix multiplication, where V is the 6×1 matrix of the output signals of the virtual sensor, M is the 6×6 matrix describing the averaging over the output signals of the real sensors, and S is the 6×1 matrix of the output signals of the real sensors.
4. The output signals of the virtual sensor are used as inputs for independent control loops operating in parallel, which have control algorithms transforming the virtual input signals V into changed signals {circumflex over (V)}.
5. The matrix {circumflex over (V)} is multiplied by a 6×6 matrix L to obtain control signals for the six coils.
6. If two compensation systems are operated directly beside each other, a 6×6 feedback, or crosscoupling matrix C is used to avoid interferences.
7. The matrix S of the output signals of the real sensors is enlarged to a 6×1 matrix Ŝ, and the control signals are calculated as O=L·Ω(M·(S−C·O)).
</summary>

<summary>
1. The invention relates to a method for investigating a sample derived from a biological source using CARS microscopy.
2. The method involves generating a resonance signal by coherent anti-Stokes Raman scattering upon excitation of at least one resonance site of the sample by means of laser irradiation.
3. The method comprises furnishing at least one resonance site by means of a bioorthogonal reaction of an intrinsic chemical structure of the sample with at least one reaction partner.
4. The at least one resonance site can be at least partly part of the at least one reaction partner or generated at least partly by the bioorthogonal reaction itself.
5. The bioorthogonal reaction can be a Diels-Alder reaction or a Staudinger ligation.
6. The method can involve furnishing resonance sites for the structures of the non-resonant background of the sample and correlating a signal component of the resonance signal attributable to those resonance sites with a signal component attributable to intrinsic resonance sites of the sample.
7. The method can be performed using a CARS microscope that comprises means for generating a pump light beam and a Stokes light beam that are directable coaxially through a microscope optical system onto a sample, and having a detector for detecting corresponding detected light.</summary>

<summary>
1. The invention provides a system for automatically assessing radiation therapy segmentations by comparing two electronic files, each providing data points describing different three-dimensional surfaces circumscribing a structure in a human patient intended for radiation therapy. The system generates volume models from the files, compares them to identify common, missing, and extra volume elements, and outputs a measure of conformance between the surfaces based on a metric method.
2. The system allows users to define custom metric methods, display cross-sectional images of the volume models with different colors for common, missing, and extra volume elements, and provide a quantitative evaluation of the comparison, including a histogram showing cumulative missing and extra volume elements as a function of distance ranges.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The invention relates to accelerating the execution of floating point operations in data processing systems, specifically focusing on the effective subtraction operation.
2. The effective subtraction operation is divided into two procedures based on the absolute value of the difference between the arguments of the exponents of the two operands (ABS{DELTA(E)}).
3. When ABS{DELTA(E)} is less than or equal to 1, the alignment of the fractions and the subtraction can be performed simultaneously, reducing the number of steps required.
4. When ABS{DELTA(E)} is greater than 1, the subtraction operation is performed to ensure a positive result, and the normalization and rounding steps are combined into a single step.
5. The invention uses a difference between a subset of signals of the operand exponent arguments (TDELTA(E)) to initiate an effective subtraction procedure before the complete difference between the exponent arguments is available, accelerating the overall process.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The invention is a method and system for tracking specimens acquired from patients in a medical facility.
2. A unique patient barcode number is assigned to each patient and stored in a database along with the patient's information.
3. A unique order barcode number is generated for each order to draw a specimen and stored in the database in relation to the patient's information and patient barcode number.
4. The patient's barcode number, order barcode number, blood drawer's barcode number, and each vial barcode number are input into a computer and stored in a relational manner in the database.
5. The computer generates a signal to acquire a specimen and places it in the container, and stores an indication of this in the database.
6. The computer compares the specimen collection time to a predetermined time and generates an error signal if the specimen collection time exceeds the predetermined time.
7. The lab processes the order with confidence using the information stored in the database linked to the vial barcode number.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The invention is a voice-activated distance measuring device for golfers, using GPS technology to provide distance and other information.
2. The device incorporates voice recognition technology to accept verbal commands from the user, sensed by a bone conductance vibration sensor or microphone.
3. The device responds to voice commands with audible output via a loudspeaker or headphone, providing distance and other information.
4. The device may also accept verbal or other data input to predict golf course user golf strategy, club selection, rules, and other player needs.
5. The device may be incorporated into an article of clothing, such as a hat or visor, or other portable device.
6. The device may use Bluetooth technology for data transfers, audio server/client, short range audio communications, and as a remote GPS.
7. The device permits recording of geographic coordinates of a golf course, including its hazards and fairway boundaries, using a portable computing device equipped with a GPS device.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The invention provides a system and method for checking design rules in integrated circuits (ICs) that contain both logic and memory circuits.
2. The method involves creating customized design rules for each type of memory region by modifying standard logic rules to accommodate more liberal memory-based parameters.
3. The customized design rules are created by running a design rule check on a memory bit cell mask pattern data against a standard logic rule command file and analyzing the resulting violations.
4. The design rule checker applies the appropriate set of rules to each region of the mask pattern data based on the type of circuit in that region.
5. The results of the design rule check are categorized by the type of region in which the error occurred, allowing for more accurate and efficient detection and correction of errors.
6. The invention can be applied to any mask pattern database, including those with no memory blocks or multiple types of memory blocks, and can be implemented using conventional GDS formatted data and software routines.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The invention uses thin substrate waveguides optically coupled to a coherent light source, such as a laser, to provide controlled illumination for objects like holograms and spatial light modulators.
2. The waveguide hologram illuminator offers advantages such as compactness, high diffraction efficiency, and minimal stray light, but also presents challenges like alignment sensitivity, illumination depletion, and two-sided diffraction, which can be addressed through various techniques.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The invention relates to testing dynamoelectric machine rotors, specifically squirrel cage rotors for induction motors, to identify defects and measure resistance, reactance, and effective electrical skew.
2. The test apparatus comprises a test head that accepts and rotates the rotor, exciting means to magnetize the rotor, voltage sensing means to generate a voltage signal responsive to rotor-induced magnetic flux, and current sensing means to sense the alternating current used for magnetization.
3. The apparatus also includes skew sensing means to sense the effective electrical skew of the rotor and generate an effective skew signal.
4. The data acquisition and processing circuit controls the acquisition of test data and processes it to produce test results and rotor pass/fail determinations.
5. The test head's core is similar to a conventional dynamoelectric machine stator, with primary windings forming at least one pair of poles and voltage pick-up coils wound over the primary coils.
6. The skew pick-up coil is located at one end of the test head, in quadrature with the poles, to sense flux build-up at the end of the rotor due to its skew characteristics.
7. The analog to digital system samples the voltage, current, and skew sense signals simultaneously and multiplexes them to an analog to digital converter, which digitizes the samples and couples them to the data processor.
8. The data processor acquires 32 samples in a cycle of the exciting alternating current, ignores samples for the next five cycles, and samples again for 32 samples, repeating this pattern for a total of forty sampling cycles to complete one rotor test sampling sequence.
9.
